timetable_clash.title: Timetable Clash
timetable_clash.info:
A timetable clash may occur between courses or class sections within a course.

If the course you are enrolling in to is a compulsory course try enrolling in to a different class section (e.g. a different seminar group).

If the course you are enrolling in to is an optional course try enrolling in to a different class section (e.g. a different seminar group), alternatively enrol in to a new course.

Download a pdf guide: Timetable clash (pdf)
Watch the how-to video: Enrolment - timetable clash

lab_swaps.info: Go to the relevant teaching office and ask about moving the lab, tutorial or seminar.

unavoidable_course_clash.title: Unavoidable Course Clash
unavoidable_course_clash.info:
If two courses you want to take clash and no workaround exists, you will need to:
  • Consult this guide
  • Speak to your adviser
  • Discuss with the lectures of the courses in person

enrol_guide.info: The registry has a useful guide for students on enrolling.

new_student.info: New students can go to  the College of Science and Engineering helpdesk (located on Boyd Orr Level 3) for help with enrolling.

add_swap.title: Add/Swap
add_swap.info:
Considering adding or swaping a course.
Before continuing consider the following
What course are you considering?
You need to know what course you are considering and whether it is sutible for you.
If you don't know what course to pick look at the course catalogue to help make a decision.
When you know what course to pick email your adviser of studies to find out if it is a sutible choice.
Are you adding or swapping?
If you are adding a course it is usually much simpler so long as it doesn't conflict with another course.
If it doesn't conflict then you can most likly do it on MyCampus. If it does conflict then read "Who will change your courses"
Are you in the Add/Drop period?
The add/drop period exists to give students time to try out courses and still be able to change without falling too far behind, therefore changing courses outside the add/drop period could result in a lot of extra work for you - especially if you have missed assessment for the course you wish to change to.
Changing courses is still possible however you should certainly discuss it with your adviser to ensure that you make the best decision for you.
Who will Change your courses You or the Collage Office?
Though you can change courses yourself in almost all situations you should goto the SSO first.
The SSO can then tell you if they can solve the problem or if you need to go to the collage office.
However going to the SSO is only nessisary when you are going to drop a course (this includes droping a course to pick another course up and any time where you will drop a course), this is beacuse they can add a course before droping one which means you will never get stuck without a course.
Getting advice on your proposed changes, are you confident?
Any time you are considering changing courses it is always recommended you discuss this with your adviser as they really are best placed to anwser questions and help you decide what is right for you.

credit_enquiries.title: How Many Credits to Take
credit_enquiries.info: Students should enroll in 120 credits (usually 60 per semester) worth of courses before the start of teaching time. If you have any further questions about taking credits, speak to a Student Support Officer.

compsci_teaching_office.title: Go to the Computing Science Teaching Office
compsci_teaching_office.info: You can find the teaching office in F161, 17 Lilybank Gardens

adviser_info.title: Adviser of Studies
adviser_info.info: To find out who your adviser of studies is, go to MyCampus->My Student Center. Their name should appear on the right of the screen. For their contact information try the Universiry staff A-Z.

transfer_outside_college.title: Transfer out of College of Science and Engineering
transfer_outside_college.info: Go to your adviser of studies and discuss your options. You will also need to contact the college that you wish to transfer to and see if they will accept you.

subcats.name: Who is my adviser of studies?

health_good_cause.title: Good Cause
health_good_cause.info: Try and follow through this flowchart to find the appropriate course of action. If you're still unsure you should speak to a Student Support Officer.

health_fit_to_study.title: Fitness to Study
health_fit_to_study.info: Sometimes, there are health or other personal issues in a student's life that prevent them from normal study on a course.  Hence they are losing time for proper preparation for subsequent assessments.  The University aims to support students in such situations, and this is formally known as "Fitness to Study" - although issues are not due to health alone.  Fitness to Study is usually first considered locally in the School.

appeals.title: Appeals
appeals.info:
For information on appeals, see the senate office page on appeals. Consider consulting your adviser on whether or not filing an appeal is the most appropriate course of action.

Additionally you can email Jane MacAllistar at senate-appeals@glasgow.ac.uk for further information on appeals.
